content.title: Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State
content.summary: Life-threatening metabolic emergency in Type 2 diabetes characterized by severe hyperglycemia, profound dehydration, and hyperosmolarity without significant ketoacidosis
key_points: Serum osmolality >320 mOsm/kg with profound dehydration
Minimal or absent ketosis (sufficient insulin to prevent ketogenesis)
Primarily affects elderly patients with T2DM
Precipitated by infection, MI, CVA, medications, or inadequate fluid intake
Treatment priority is aggressive fluid resuscitation (average 9L deficit)
content.statement: Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) is an acute, life-threatening metabolic complication of Type 2 diabetes characterized by severe hyperglycemia, profound dehydration, and hyperosmolarity without significant ketoacidosis, carrying higher mortality than DKA.

explanation.intuition: In HHS, there is just enough insulin to prevent fat breakdown (ketogenesis) but not enough to control glucose. The result is extreme hyperglycemia that draws water from cells via osmosis, causing severe dehydration and altered mental status.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike DKA where insulin is completely absent, HHS patients have residual insulin that prevents ketone formation. This allows glucose to rise much higher before symptoms force medical attention, resulting in more severe dehydration and higher mortality.
explanation.technical_details: The pathophysiology involves relative insulin deficiency with elevated counter-regulatory hormones causing hepatic gluconeogenesis and impaired peripheral glucose utilization. Residual insulin suppresses lipolysis and ketogenesis. Osmotic diuresis from glycosuria causes massive fluid and electrolyte losses. Decreased GFR from dehydration further impairs glucose excretion.

definitions_glossary.hyperosmolarity: Abnormally increased osmotic concentration of body fluids (>320 mOsm/kg)
definitions_glossary.effective_osmolality: Calculated as 2×Na + glucose/18; excludes BUN which freely crosses membranes
definitions_glossary.osmotic_diuresis: Excessive urination caused by non-reabsorbable solutes (glucose) in renal tubules
definitions_glossary.mental_status_changes: Neurological symptoms correlating with osmolality; obtundation, seizures, coma
definitions_glossary.relative_insulin_deficiency: Insufficient insulin for metabolic demands but enough to prevent ketogenesis
definitions_glossary.precipitating_factors: Triggers including infection, MI, CVA, medications, dehydration
definitions_glossary.corrected_sodium: Adjusted sodium accounting for dilutional effect of hyperglycemia
definitions_glossary.free_water_deficit: Calculated water loss requiring replacement: 0.6 × weight × (1 - 140/Na)
definitions_glossary.rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown that can occur in severe HHS due to hyperosmolarity
definitions_glossary.cerebral_edema: Brain swelling from rapid osmolality correction; more common in children
definitions_glossary.overlap_syndrome: Mixed features of both HHS and DKA occurring simultaneously
definitions_glossary.insensible_losses: Ongoing fluid losses through respiration and skin

pathophysiology.mechanism: Relative insulin deficiency with elevated counter-regulatory hormones causing severe hyperglycemia, hyperosmolarity, and profound dehydration without significant ketosis
key_differences_from_dka: Sufficient insulin to suppress lipolysis and ketogenesis
More common in elderly with T2DM
precipitating_factors: Infection (40-60% of cases) - pneumonia, UTI most common
dehydration_consequences: Decreased GFR impairs renal glucose excretion

clinical_presentation: Polyuria and polydipsia (often for days to weeks)
diagnostic_criteria.mental_status_correlation: Neurological symptoms correlate with osmolality: confusion at 320-340, obtundation 340-370, coma >370 mOsm/kg

fluid_resuscitation.priority: Fluids are MORE important than insulin in HHS
fluid_resuscitation.subsequent: 0.45% NaCl 250-500 mL/hr based on corrected sodium
fluid_resuscitation.rate_adjustment: Slower correction if elderly or cardiac disease
fluid_resuscitation.monitoring: Target 3-4 L in first 4 hours, 50% of deficit in 12 hours
fluid_resuscitation.glucose_containing_fluids: Add D5 when glucose reaches 250-300 mg/dL

insulin_therapy.timing: Start after initial fluid bolus and if K+ ≥3.3 mEq/L
insulin_therapy.regimen: 0.1 units/kg/hr IV regular insulin (lower than DKA)
insulin_therapy.caution: Avoid rapid glucose correction to prevent cerebral edema

electrolyte_management.potassium: Replace if K+ <5.3 mEq/L; hold insulin if K+ <3.3 mEq/L

treatment_options.thromboprophylaxis: Consider prophylactic anticoagulation due to high thrombotic risk

skos.definition: A life-threatening metabolic emergency characterized by severe hyperglycemia, profound dehydration, and hyperosmolarity without significant ketoacidosis, primarily affecting elderly patients with Type 2 diabetes

icd10.description: Type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperosmolarity without nonketotic hyperglycemic-hyperosmolar coma (NKHHC)
subcodes: E11.01 - Type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperosmolarity with coma

learning_objectives: Differentiate HHS from DKA based on clinical and laboratory features
Calculate serum osmolality and corrected sodium in hyperglycemic emergencies
Prioritize fluid resuscitation over insulin therapy in HHS management
Recognize precipitating factors and underlying causes of HHS
Prevent complications including thromboembolism, cerebral edema, and rhabdomyolysis
clinical_pearls: HHS has higher mortality than DKA (10-20% vs 1-5%) despite less dramatic presentation
Fluid resuscitation is the primary therapy - insulin is secondary in HHS
Mental status correlates with osmolality, not glucose level
Calculate effective osmolality (2×Na + glucose/18) to assess severity
Consider DVT prophylaxis - HHS patients are hypercoagulable
Avoid rapid glucose/osmolality correction to prevent cerebral edema
Many patients have overlap features of both HHS and DKA
Correct sodium for glucose: add 1.6-2.4 mEq/L for each 100 mg/dL glucose above 100
